Opening the doors to foreign students allows the brightest minds to freely circulate ideas, gain global knowledge and build their skills. As with some other CDI measures (namely poverty focus of development finance, inflow of migrants, trade tariffs and university collaborations) we give proportionally higher scores the poorer are the beneficiaries of CDI countries’ policies. To do so, we weigh the raw data by the income of students’ country of origin.  

Student data, both on foreign students as well as on the total tertiary student body come from UNESCO. GNI per capita, PPP data for the countries of origin of the foreign students come from the World Bank’s World Development Indicators. The method of calculating the income weights for each origin country is outlined in the CDI methodology.  

The weight of this indicator in the technology component is 25 percent.

female-students.name: Female Students
female-students.description:
% of total foreign students

This indicator measures the share of total international students who are female. Admitting female foreign students is especially important for development as this frequently has stronger social remittance effects , and can promote gender equality in their home countries. Therefore, countries are rewarded for having more female students. Data on students’ gender breakdown was taken from UNESCO.  

A CDI country’s score on the female students’ indicator is its total foreign female tertiary students divided by its total foreign tertiary students.  

The weight of this indicator in the technology component is 10 percent.

research-collaboration.name: Research Collaboration
research-collaboration.description:
Lower-income weighted shares of co-authored international outputs

This indicator measures the share of a CDI country’s research outputs (as measured by journal publications) which are co-published by authors affiliated with third countries as a proportion of all internationally co-authored outputs. Collaborations with lower-income countries are given a higher weight. Scientific collaboration is an important mechanism enabling spillovers through the integration of developing countries into research activities, thereby promoting both knowledge transfers and diffusion (González-Alcaide et al., 2017). More widely, co-authorship across multiple countries is associated with higher quality knowledge generation. Through collaborating, global researchers can integrate a wide range of competences and skills to attack difficult problems with an enhanced chance of success. Accordingly, co-authored papers also tend to have a higher impact (Pan et al., 2012).  

Data are provided by SCOPUS, Elsevier’s abstract and citation database, and accessed through the SciVal platform. Publications in the latest year available (2022)are measured and the nationality of authors was determined by the country of their institutional affiliation. To understand the relative share of outputs which are co-authored with lower-income countries, we weight research outputs by the weight assigned to the country of the international co-authors: we give a higher score for research outputs co-published with poorer countries. The income weights for each co-authoring country are outlined in the methodology. The income-weighted share of co-authored articles by a CDI country is divided by its total internationally co-authored articles to measure the degree of co-authoring with relatively poorer countries when it cooperated internationally.  

The weight of this indicator in the technology component is 10 percent.

intellectual-property-rights.name: Intellectual Property Rights
intellectual-property-rights.description:
Score on refraining from restrictions beyond WTO standards

This indicator measures the restrictiveness of intellectual property right (IPR) provisions in free trade agreements between CDI countries and developing countries. IPRs aim to incentivize research and innovation by granting producers of new technologies a monopoly over their inventions for a specified period. But a developmental IPR regime needs to balance this incentive with the need to sufficiently enable others to make use of vital technologies (including, but not limited to vaccines or medicines). The CDI therefore measures the degree to which CDI countries include IPR clauses in their bilateral free trade agreements with developing countries that are more restrictive than the IPR safeguards already upheld by the WTO as part of the TRIPS+ agreement.

Data for this indicator was compiled by Political Watch (formerly CIECODE), who analysed the legal provisions in free trade agreements between CDI countries and developing countries for the restrictiveness of their IPR provisions on content relating to (1) patent term length; (2) patent opposition and revocation systems; (3) compulsory licensing; (4) parallel imports; and (5) counterfeiting. Any provisions which are more restrictive than the WTO TRIPS+ agreement result in no points. Further details can be found in the CDI methodology.

The weight of this indicator in the technology component is 20 percent.
